choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Good response to steroids

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is a type of glomerulonephritis that typically affects children and is characterized by the presence of nephrotic syndrome. The following statement is true about this condition:

 

  • Good response to steroids: MCD is often considered to be the most steroid-responsive form of nephrotic syndrome. The vast majority of children with MCD respond well to treatment with corticosteroids, with complete remission of proteinuria and edema occurring in over 90% of cases. However, the response to steroids may be less predictable in adults with MCD.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes: Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes (not light microscopy)

 

Option C. Most common in adults: it is common in pediatric age group, not adults

 

Option D. Non-selective proteinuria: the patient will have massive nephrotic range proteinuria.

 

The causes of MCD are mostly idiopathic. It is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines), respiratory infections, prophylactic immunizations, eczema, and rhinitis.

 

 

Clinically, they mostly present with proteinuria. The child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalized edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and has a very good response to corticosteroid treatment, resulting in complete remission of proteinuria and edema in over 90% of cases.

questions.text: In a diabetic patient, the following lesions are present in the armpit. What would be observed during a Wood's lamp examination? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coral red fluorescence.

 

  • The clinical scenario of a diabetic patient, along with the observed hyperpigmented lesion in axilla strongly suggests erythrasma.
  • Coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination is the characteristic finding in this disease.

 

 

Erythrasma

 

  • It is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with diabetes and weakened immune systems and is associated with factors such as obesity, excessive sweating, and poor hygiene.
  • The characteristic feature of erythrasma is the presence of hyperpigmented patches that are typically asymptomatic. These patches commonly appear in areas like the axilla, groin, intergluteal, and sub-mammary regions.
  • The coral pink fluorescence observed during Wood's lamp examination is a defining feature of erythrasma and is caused by coproporphyrin III, a pigment produced by the bacterium.

 

 

  • Wood's lamp uses ultraviolet wavelength light at 365nm (320-400nm) with a peak at 365nm. The filter of the Wood's lamp is composed of Barium silicate and 9% Nickel oxide.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Yellow fluorescence: Often seen with Pityriasis versicolor, which fluoresces yellow or apple green due to the presence of tryptophan metabolites produced by Malassezia species.

 

Option C. Blue fluorescence: Not commonly associated with bacterial or fungal infections of the skin but may appear in certain conditions unrelated to common skin infections.

 

Option D. Green fluorescence: Typically observed with Pseudomonas infections or some cases of Tinea capitis caused by fungi that produce substances that fluoresce green.

 

Additional Information

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page no 26.40

Image source: https://dermnetnz.org/assets/Uploads/bacterial/erythrasma13__WatermarkedWyJXYXRlcm1hcmtlZCJd.jpg

questions.text: A chorionic villous sampling is done at 12 weeks in a woman whose blood group is B negative. Her husband's blood group is A positive. What is the dose of Anti D given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 50

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of Rh incompatibility, where the mother is Rh-negative (B negative) and the father is Rh-positive (A positive), there is a risk of fetal-maternal hemorrhage (FMH) during invasive procedures like chorionic villous sampling (CVS). This can lead to the mixing of fetal and maternal blood, potentially causing the mother to form antibodies against the Rh-positive fetal red blood cells. To prevent this alloimmunization, an Anti-D immunoglobulin injection is administered.

 

The standard practice is to give Anti-D immunoglobulin during any inciting event (e.g., CVS, amniocentesis, abdominal trauma, abruption, placenta previa) and at delivery. Additionally, it is given prophylactically at 28 weeks of gestation to all Rh-negative women.

 

The dosage of Anti-D depends on the gestational age:

 

 

Less than 12 weeks: 50 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

More than 12 weeks: 300 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

Since the CVS was performed at 12 weeks, the appropriate dose of Anti-D is 50 micrograms.

 

Educational objective:

 

For Rh-negative women undergoing an inciting event like chorionic villous sampling at less than 12 weeks gestation, the dose of Anti-D given is 50 micrograms.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient. Na+: 145 mEq/L, K+ 4 mEq/L Cl: 90 mEq/L HCO3: 20 mEq/L. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 35


The anion gap is calculated using the formula:

 

Anion Gap = Na−(Cl+HCO3)
 

Anion Gap=145−(90+20)=35

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anion gap is calculated as Na - (Cl + HCO3), and a high anion gap may indicate metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Based on the patient's history of relapsing, remitting, mildly itchy erythematous plaques on the scalp, sacral area, and knees, along with joint pain and the displayed nail changes in the image below, what would be your diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriasis

 

The diagnosis in this patient showing nail pitting, oil drop sign, and salmon patches in fingernails is psoriasis.

 

  • The nail changes shown in the image, such as nail pitting and onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed), along with the patient's history of itchy erythematous plaques and joint pain, are characteristic of psoriasis.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

Pitting affecting the fingernails

 

 

Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adult-onset Still's disease:

 

This systemic inflammatory condition typically presents with a salmon-pink rash, fever, and arthritis but is not typically associated with the nail changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Pachyonychia congenita:

 

A rare genetic condition affecting the nails, characterized by thickened nails (pachyonychia) as seen in the image below.

 

 

Option D. Lichen planus:

 

This condition can affect the nails, causing thinning and splitting, and it can also lead to lacy white lesions on the mucous membranes (Wickham's striae), but the nail changes in the image are more characteristic of psoriasis, and lichen planus doesn’t commonly cause joint pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When presented with nail pitting, onycholysis, erythematous plaques with scales on common sites such as the scalp, sacral area, and knees, along with joint pain, consider psoriasis as a likely diagnosis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.4-35.6

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

choices.text: Pre- invasive diagnostic test

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue pregnancy

 

Explanation

 

  • The risks for malformations, growth restriction, or abortion are not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).
  • Since diagnostic X-rays seldom exceed 0.1 Gy (10 rads), the risk is negligible. A 0.1 Gy exposure is equivalent to more than 1000 chest X-rays.
  • Hence, continuing pregnancy is the most appropriate advice to this woman.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Terminate pregnancy: Termination is not necessary as the radiation dose from a single chest X-ray is significantly lower than the threshold for increased risks.

 

Option C. Pre-invasive diagnostic test: This is not required in this scenario as the radiation dose is too low to justify invasive diagnostics.

 

Option D. Chromosome screening: Chromosome screening is unnecessary because the radiation dose from a chest X-ray does not significantly increase the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective

 

The risk for fetal malformations, growth restriction, or abortion is not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).

 

Ref: Page 2265, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes for a follow-up visit after a vasectomy. How long should he and his partner continue using a barrier method of contraception after the procedure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16 Weeks

 

Following Vasectomy, the use of barrier methods of contraception are recommended for 3 months or 12 weeks, as even though it is a permanent method, the spermatozoa takes up to three months to clear out from the tract/ ejaculatory ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-vasectomy, it is recommended to continue using a barrier contraceptive method for 12-16 weeks to ensure that all remaining sperm have been cleared from the ejaculatory ducts.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Bronchoscopy
  2. Computed tomography scan
  3. ICD insertion
  4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

 

A child presenting with a history of choking and decreased air entry in the left lung is highly suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the left bronchus. The correct management steps include:

 

1. Bronchoscopy: This is the gold standard for both the diagnosis and removal of the foreign body. Rigid bronchoscopy is typically performed by a specialist, such as an otolaryngologist or pulmonologist, to visualize and extract the foreign body.

 

4. Chest X-ray: This is an essential initial investigation to assess for the presence of a foreign body. Although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary findings such as air trapping, obstructive emphysema, atelectasis, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, and consolidation can be indicative of foreign body aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

2. CT scan: While a CT scan has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting radiolucent foreign bodies, it is not routinely performed in this situation due to the high radiation exposure, especially in children.

 

3. ICD insertion: Insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) is not indicated unless there is clinical evidence of pneumothorax or other complications that require it. A chest X-ray is essential before deciding on this intervention.

 

Clinical Approach:

 

  • A detailed history and physical examination are critical when a child presents with choking.
  • A chest X-ray should be performed to assess for secondary signs of foreign body aspiration.
  • Bronchoscopy should be conducted even if imaging is negative but clinical suspicion remains high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C5

 

Explanation:

 

The most likely cause of the inability to abduct the arm is a C5 root lesion.

 

The C5 spinal nerve plays a crucial role in controlling shoulder abduction. It gives rise to the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. Damage or compression of the C5 nerve root or axillary nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to difficulty in abducting the arm.

 

Deltoid is supplied by axillary nerve which has the root value of C4-C6. The C5 component is responsible for abduction.Other components help in flexion and extensionm at shoulder joint

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C4: The C4 spinal nerve does not directly innervate the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction. It primarily supplies sensory information to areas of the neck and upper shoulders.

 

Option C. C6: The C6 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow flexion and wrist extension, not shoulder abduction. Damage to the C6 nerve root would affect these functions rather than shoulder abduction.

 

Option D. C7: The C7 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow and wrist flexion and finger extension. It is not directly involved in shoulder abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the shoulder

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass as shown in the image below. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT angiogram

  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a rare type of vascular malformation that involves the dilation of multiple blood vessels and their adjacent tissue, resulting in a tangled mass of blood vessels resembling a "bag of worms".
  • These aneurysms are most commonly found in the scalp, face, and neck regions, but can occur in other parts of the body as well.
  • Symptoms may include visible swelling, throbbing or pulsating sensation, pain, and potential for bleeding or rupture.
  • Diagnosis of cirsoid aneurysm is typically made through imaging tests such as USG Doppler, CT, MRI, or angiography.
  • If the pulsatile mass is suspected to be a vascular lesion or aneurysm, a CT angiogram would be a suitable choice as it provides detailed visualization of the blood vessels, and can help define the anatomy and blood supply of the lesion.
  • It aids in planning therapeutic interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (functional endoscopic sinus surgery): FESS is a procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. It involves using an endoscope to view and remove the sinus blockages. This procedure is not relevant to the diagnosis or management of a vascular malformation like cirsoid aneurysm.

 

Option B. Needle aspiration: Needle aspiration is contraindicated in this scenario due to the risk of bleeding. Attempting to aspirate a pulsatile vascular lesion can lead to significant hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Intravenous antibiotics for 7 days: Intravenous antibiotics are typically used to treat infections. While pain and tenderness might suggest an infectious process, the presence of a pulsatile mass strongly suggests a vascular etiology, making antibiotics inappropriate as a primary intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A CT angiogram is crucial for diagnosing and planning the treatment of a cirsoid aneurysm due to its detailed visualization of blood vessels.
  • Needle aspiration is contraindicated due to the risk of bleeding.

choices.text: Descending paralysis is seen
Plasmapheresis is a treatment method

questions.text: All are true about Typical Guillain-Barre syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Descending paralysis is seen

 

Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) is typically characterized by ascending paralysis, starting from the lower extremities and moving upward, not descending paralysis. This pattern begins with weakness in the legs that spreads to the upper limbs and the face, associated with the demyelination of peripheral nerves. The condition is indeed inflammatory and primarily affects the peripheral nervous system, leading to demyelination and sometimes axonal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammatory condition: True, GBS is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy.

 

Option C. Plasmapheresis is a treatment method: True, plasmapheresis is used to remove antibodies from the blood that are thought to be involved in the immune attack on the peripheral nerves.

 

Option D. Demyelinating disorder: True, GBS involves the demyelination of peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GBS produces neuro-radiculopathy due to demyelination causing ascending paralysis.

 

Causes of Descending paralysis (Mnemonic: Bipolar disorder [BPD]):

 

B: Botulism

P: Porphyria, Polio

D: Diphtheria

choices.text: Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with no significant medical history, who has been using depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) for contraception, presents to the clinic after missing her scheduled injection by 14 days. She denies any sexual activity since her last injection. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago, and she has no signs of pregnancy. What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient regarding contraception? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Give DMPA

 

Explanation:

 

  • As per the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, ideally Inj DMPA (Antara) should be administered 3 monthly as shown in the table below:

 

Follow up of clients (coming on scheduled date for next injection i.e after 3 months

 

 

  • Defaulter: A defaulter is a client who does not return for the next injection on the scheduled date; but comes for it within the grace period i.e. 2 weeks earlier and upto 4 weeks later from the scheduled date).

 

 

Drop out: A dropout is a MPAclient who comes for the next injection after the grace period of 4 weeks is over and more than 4 months have passed since she took her last injection

 

 

In the scenario mentioned above, the patient is a DEFAULTER and hence the Inj should be administered as she falls within the grace period

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UPT before DMPA: This would be appropriate if the patient was a drop-out, i.e. if she had presented > 4 weeks of the date that she had to come on. 

 

Option C. Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier: This approach would be recommended if the injection was delayed beyond 4 weeks. 

 

Option D. Wait till next period: This unnecessarily delays contraceptive protection and is not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient misses her scheduled DMPA injection by up to 30 days, the most appropriate recommendation is to administer DMPA directly without pregnancy testing. 

  • This is because Inj DMPA is known to cause a delayed return to fertlity. 

  • This ensures continuous contraceptive protection while following evidence-based guidelines that balance safety with practical clinical considerations.

questions.text: A nulliparous woman presented with 26 weeks of gestation for routine antenatal check-up. Her blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg. What can be the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine dipstick

 

  • A pregnant woman with BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation should be evaluated for gestational hypertension or Pre-eclampsia.
  • So, the next step should be looking out for proteinuria by Urine dipstick test.  (Here Proteinuria refers to urine dipstick greater than or equal to +2 (1 gm/L) on at least two random clean catch samples   or a  total 24 hour urine protein > 0.3 gm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum Uric Acid: Blood changes in pre-eclampsia may not be very specific however a serum Uric acid of more than 4.5 mg/dl may be considered as a biochemical marker

 

Option B. Liver Function tests and Option C. Complete blood count: LFTs may be raised and there may altered coagulation profile and thrombocytopenia

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation, the next best step is to evaluate for proteinuria using a urine dipstick test to screen for pre-eclampsia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics page 256, 262

questions.text: A neonate on breast feeding develops jaundice. Urine Benedict’s test is positive. The enzyme deficiency is_________: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-P Uridyl Transferase

 

This is the enzyme deficient in classic galactosemia, a condition where galactose accumulates in the blood. This occurs because the neonate's diet (breast milk or formula) contains lactose, which is broken down into glucose and galactose. The inability to further metabolize galactose leads to its accumulation, causing symptoms like jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a positive Benedict's test (due to the presence of reducing sugars like galactose in the urine).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactokinase: While a deficiency in galactokinase can cause galactosemia, the clinical presentation is typically milder compared to galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency. Galactokinase deficiency usually leads to cataract formation due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye, but it doesn't typically cause severe jaundice or a positive Benedict's test, which indicates the presence of reducing sugars (like galactose) in urine.

 

 

Option C. Lactose: Lactose is a disaccharide composed of glucose and galactose, not an enzyme. Deficiency of lactase, the enzyme that breaks down lactose, leads to lactose intolerance, which typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, diarrhea, and gas, but not jaundice or a positive Benedict's test.

 

Option D. Aldolase B: Aldolase B deficiency leads to hereditary fructose intolerance. When fructose (from fruits, sweeteners, and some infant formulas) is ingested, it cannot be properly metabolized, leading to hypoglycemia and other symptoms. This condition does not lead to the accumulation of galactose, hence not causing the symptoms seen in this neonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neonate's symptoms, including jaundice and a positive Benedict's test for reducing sugars in the urine, are indicative of galactosemia. In galactosemia, there is a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, which is involved in the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate. Gal-1-P accumulates causes product inhibition of galactokinase resulting in galactose accumulation which comes out in urine giving positive Benedict’s test.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 198

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kaposi sarcoma

 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a common malignancy in patients with HIV/AIDS. It is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and typically presents as painless or painful, violaceous (purple) lesions on the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral cavity. The image shows such a lesion on the palate, which is characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma. These lesions are vascular in nature and can vary in color from red to purple, often with a raised or nodular appearance. In HIV patients, Kaposi sarcoma is an AIDS-defining condition and is often seen in those with significant immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer usually occurs in sun-exposed areas of the skin and rarely affects mucous membranes. It typically presents as a pearly or waxy bump, not as multiple purple lesions.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: While melanomas can appear as pigmented lesions, they are usually black or brown and rarely present as multiple violaceous lesions in the oral cavity.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer can occur in the oral cavity but usually presents as a non-healing ulcer or a raised, firm, scaly plaque. It does not have the characteristic color and appearance of Kaposi sarcoma lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi sarcoma should be suspected in HIV patients presenting with violaceous lesions on the skin or mucous membranes. It is an AIDS-defining condition associated with HHV-8 infection.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas report is as follows: pH 7.2, pCO2 81mm Hg, and HCO3 40 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

The arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows a pH of 7.2, which indicates acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is elevated at 81 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), indicating that the acidosis is due to a respiratory cause, as CO2 retention leads to respiratory acidosis.

 

The bicarbonate (HCO3) level is elevated at 40 mEq/L (normal range: 22-28 mEq/L). This elevation suggests that the kidneys are compensating for the respiratory acidosis by retaining bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions, indicating a chronic component to the respiratory acidosis.

 

In summary, the primary disturbance is respiratory acidosis, evidenced by the elevated pCO2, and the elevated bicarbonate suggests a compensatory response by the kidneys, characteristic of chronic respiratory acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and low pCO2, which is the opposite of the findings in this ABG report.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis would present with a low pH and a low bicarbonate level. However, in this case, the bicarbonate is elevated, not decreased, indicating the primary issue is not metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and elevated bicarbonate, but without the accompanying high pCO2. The presence of high pCO2 and low pH indicates the primary disturbance is respiratory, not metabolic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blood gas report showing low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory elevated bicarbonate indicates respiratory acidosis, often with a chronic component if the bicarbonate is significantly elevated.

questions.text: The image shows changes in membrane potential during an action potential. The region marked between 4 to 5 is due to?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Efflux of K+

 

The action potential curve shows the different phases of an action potential in a neuron. The region marked between 4 and 5 corresponds to repolarization and hyperpolarization.

 

  • Phase 4 to 5 (Repolarization and Hyperpolarization): During this phase, voltage-gated potassium channels remain open, and there is an efflux of K+ ions from the cell, causing the membrane potential to return to the resting level or even become more negative (hyperpolarization).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Influx of Na+: This occurs during the depolarization phase (Phase 0 to 1), not during repolarization.

 

Option B. Efflux of Na+: This does not occur in the action potential phases.

 

Option C. Influx of K+: Potassium ions typically move out of the cell (efflux) during repolarization, not into the cell.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old P2L2 woman presents with cervical elongation. Her family is complete. What is the preferred surgery advised? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fothergill


The Fothergill procedure, also known as the Manchester repair, is the preferred surgical treatment for women with cervical elongation who have completed their families and do not wish to have more children. This procedure involves cervical amputation and reinforcement of the pelvic ligaments, providing adequate support without removing the uterus. It is suitable for younger women who are not candidates for a hysterectomy but have significant cervical elongation contributing to prolapse symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. McCall Culdoplasty: This procedure is typically performed to correct vaginal vault prolapse during or after hysterectomy and is not specifically indicated for cervical elongation.

 

Option C. Le fort: This procedure involves partial closure of the vagina and is generally recommended for elderly, non-sexually active women who are not candidates for more invasive surgeries.

 

Option D. Shirodkar sling: This procedure is used for pelvic organ prolapse in young, nulliparous women or women who wish to preserve fertility by anchoring the uterus, usually to the sacral promontory. It is not indicated for women with completed families and cervical elongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolapse management by age group:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive method? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparoscopic tubal ligation


Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent form of contraception and is not classified as a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC). It involves the surgical closure or blocking of the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy permanently.

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC) methods are effective for extended periods and can be reversed if desired. They include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper T: Correct. Copper T is an intrauterine device (IUD) that can provide contraception for several years.

 

Option B. Implanon: Correct. Implanon is a type of contraceptive implant that provides effective contraception for several years.

 

Option D. SC DMPA: This is a LARC. It is a sub cutaneous preparation of depot medroxy progesterone acetate and is administered once in 3 months

 

Educational Objective:


Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent method of contraception and is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC).

questions.text:
A 73-year-old individual arrives with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the listed investigations are conducted for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Colonoscopy
  2. CECT
  3. CEA
  4. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

 

1. Colonoscopy: This is an endoscopic examination of the large bowel and the distal part of the small bowel. It provides a visual diagnosis and can offer biopsy or removal of suspected lesions. It is an essential diagnostic tool for any patient with per-rectal bleeding to identify potential sources such as polyps, tumors, or colitis.

 

2. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):  CECT can provide detailed cross-sectional images of the body. In the context of rectal bleeding, it might be used to evaluate the extent of a detected tumor, check for metastatic disease, or to view vascular anomalies that might be causing the bleeding, such as arteriovenous malformations.

 

3. CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen): CEA is a tumor marker. Its level can be elevated in colorectal cancers as well as other malignancies and conditions. Monitoring the levels of CEA might help in diagnosing, prognosis, and checking the recurrence of colorectal cancers. 

 

Other Option:

 

4. CA 19-9: CA 19-9 is another tumor marker. It is more typically associated with pancreatic cancer. However, its specificity for colorectal cancer is not as high as CEA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the patient's presenting symptom of painless rectal bleeding:

 

  • Colonoscopy is a primary diagnostic tool to visualize and biopsy any potential sources of bleeding.
  • CECT could be useful in determining the extent of a potential tumor or to check for other causes of bleeding.
  • CEA might be used to check for the possibility of colorectal cancer.

 

Hence, the investigations that would be most appropriate and relevant for this patient would be options 1, 2, and 3. Therefore, answer choice D) 1, 2, and 3 is correct.

choices.text: Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors

questions.text: An elderly woman received a Botox injection for the treatment of wrinkles.  Which of the following is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

 

  • The botulinum toxin works by preventing acetylcholine from entering the synaptic cleft. Acetylcholine is exocytosed by SNARE protein, which is broken down by botulinum toxin. Consequently, it prevents acetylcholine from being released.
  • Other agents that regulate the level of Ach in the synapse are:
    • Hemicholinium acts by inhibiting choline uptake (the rate limiting step in the synthesis of acetylcholine)
    • Vesamicol inhibits the uptake of Acetylcholine into the vesicles.
    • Physostigmine inhibits the breakdown of Ach at the synaptic cleft by the action of Acetylcholine esterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft: Botulinum toxin does not facilitate the release of noradrenaline. Its primary action is on the cholinergic neurons where it inhibits the release of acetylcholine.

 

Option C. Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not directly inhibit nicotinic receptors. Instead, it prevents the release of acetylcholine, which means there is no neurotransmitter available to bind to and activate the nicotinic receptors.

 

Option D. Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not stimulate muscarinic or nicotinic receptors. In fact, it decreases neurotransmission by preventing the release of acetylcholine, which would otherwise stimulate these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine by cleaving SNARE proteins, thereby preventing neurotransmission at the neuromuscular junction and leading to muscle relaxation.

questions.text: All of the following are types of polysaccharide vaccines except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant type of subunit vaccine, which means it is made using genetic engineering techniques to produce the surface antigens of the Hepatitis B virus

 

Other Options:

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response specifically against the polysaccharides found on the surface of certain bacterial capsules. These vaccines include:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae B (Hib) vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

These vaccines may also be available as glycoconjugate vaccines, which are designed to improve immunogenicity, especially in younger populations. However, the vaccine for Salmonella Typhimurium (Typhim VI) is available only in a polysaccharide form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines include those for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Note - Polysaccharide vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies specifically against the polysaccharide components of the bacterial capsule. These polysaccharides are unique to particular strains or serotypes of bacteria, making the vaccine effective in targeting those specific types.

 

Limitations of Polysaccharide vaccines: serotype-specific and do not facilitate herd immunity due to their lack of a robust T-cell response.

questions.text: Low transferrin saturation is seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Low transferrin saturation is indicative of inadequate iron within the body to fully saturate transferrin, which is the main protein in the blood that binds to iron and transports it throughout the body. This condition is a hallmark of iron deficiency anemia, where there is a decreased level of total body iron.

 

Transferrin Saturation (%) = (Serum Iron / Total Iron-Binding Capacity) × 100

 

  • Normal: ~20–45%
  • Low: Indicates not enough iron bound to transferrin
  • High: Indicates excess circulating iron

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemochromatosis: Incorrect because this is characterized by increased iron levels in the body, typically leading to high transferrin saturation.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: Incorrect because this is a genetic disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, not primarily associated with iron deficiency.

 

Option D. Megaloblastic anemia: Incorrect as this anemia type is usually due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, not iron.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low transferrin saturation is a significant marker for diagnosing iron deficiency anemia, reflecting a shortfall in available iron for red blood cell production.

questions.text: Which of the following growth hormone analogue that is not used for treatment of GH deficiency but is used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tesamorelin

 

Tesamorelin is a synthetic analogue of growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) that is specifically used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, a condition characterized by abnormal distribution of body fat in patients with HIV. Tesamorelin reduces visceral adipose tissue and improves the body composition of individuals with this condition. Unlike other growth hormone analogues, Tesamorelin is not primarily used for treating growth hormone deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sermorelin: Sermorelin is a synthetic analogue of GHRH used to diagnose and treat growth hormone deficiency. It is not indicated for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option C. Somatropin: Somatropin is a recombinant form of human growth hormone used to treat growth hormone deficiencies. It is not used for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It is not used for HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tesamorelin is a growth hormone-releasing hormone analogue used specifically for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, distinguishing it from other growth hormone analogues that are used for treating growth hormone deficiencies.

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal 1/3rd

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Salient features: 

    • It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 

    • Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 

    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. 

    • Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.

  • Most common location:              

    • Adults and adolescents: Middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%). 

    • Children: Distal pole avulsion type fracture.

  • Pathogenesis of AVN:

    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 

    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.

    • Thus, the proximal third of the scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis (AVN) due to its precarious retrograde blood supply. 

    • Fracture in the waist (middle third) can disrupt this blood flow to the proximal fragment, leading to AVN.

  • Diagnosis: 

    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possible fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.

    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.

    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.

    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.

  • Treatment:

    • Nondisplaced, Stable Scaphoid Fractures: Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast.

    • Displaced, Unstable Scaphoid Fractures: Headless Screw (Herbert) is used

    • Complication: Non-union > Avascular Necrosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distal 1/3rd. Distal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid is a well vascularized area, so fracture to this part is often undisplaced or minimally displaced, thus they heal faster with conservative management. This portion of scaphoid is fractured in 10% of cases. AVN of this part occurs in 1% cases. 

 

Option B. Middle 1/3rd. Middle 1/3rd or the waist of scaphoid is most commonly fractures, accounting for 70% of cases. But the chances of AVN at this portion are around 20%. 

 

Option D. Scaphoid tubercle. Avulsion fracture of scaphoid tubercle are rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proximal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid have less chances of fracture (20%) but have higher chances of AVN (40%).

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scalp, dura, arachnoid

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the illustration, which displays a baby's skull, is pointing in the direction of the anterior fontanelle. Ventricular tapping is the term used to describe the process of removing CSF from the anterior fontanelle. The various structures pierced are the scalp, dura, and arachnoid.

 

Fontanelle tap/ Percutaneous ventricular puncture:

 

Infants who need urgent ventricular decompression and have an open anterior fontanelle and no access to a VP shunt undergo a fontanelle tap or percutaneous ventricular puncture. A butterfly needle is used to immediately puncture the infant's open fontanelle and enter the lateral ventricle in order to obtain CS samples, alleviate pressure, or insert a drain or catheter.

 

Procedure: A 25-gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus).

 

When performing a fontanelle tap, the following layers are pierced:

 

  • Scalp: This includes the skin and the underlying connective tissue of the scalp.
  • Membranous fontanelle: The actual fontanelle is a soft spot on a baby's head where the bones of the skull have not yet fused together. It's a membranous gap between the cranial bones.
  • Dura mater: The tough outermost membrane of the three layers of the meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord.
  • Arachnoid mater: A thin, wispy layer that lies underneath the dura mater.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): Once through the arachanoid mater, the needle enters the subarachnoid space where the CSF is located.

 

Note: The fontanelle tap bypasses the bony skull, which is why it's an accessible route in neonates and infants for procedures that require access to the CSF. However, as the child grows, these fontanelles close, and the method is no longer viable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fontanelle tap is a critical emergency procedure used in infants for CSF sampling or pressure relief from the ventricles, exploiting the unossified sections of the skull for direct access to the CSF. This procedure is unique to neonates and young infants where the fontanelle is present and typically involves piercing the scalp, dura, and arachnoid layers.

choices.text: Kwashiorkor due to less energy intake
Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake
Marasmus due to less energy intake
Marasmus due to less protein intake

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by her grandmother Which of the following is correct about the given image? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake

 

The given image is suggestive of kwashiorkor, as it shows a bulging abdomen and pedal edema along with thin limbs and prominent ribs. Kwashiorkor occurs as a result of less protein intake, whereas marasmus occurs due to less calorie intake.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the level of the cross-section shown in the image below. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. T4-T5

 

Explanation:

 

The cross-section shown in the image is at the level of T4-T5.

 

Ascending and Descending aorta are visible separately along with bifurcation of pulmonary trunk, this implies it is the section of T4-T5 level.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, Option B: In cross-sections at the levels of T1-T2 and T2-T3, only the small vascular openings of the branches arising from the arch of aorta would be visible.

 

Option C: In cross section of T3-T4 level  - section of arch of aorta along with branches of arch of aorta would be visible

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bifurcation of pulmonary trunk along with separate ascending and descending aorta are clearing pointing towards T4-T5 level.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures does not form part of the laryngeal skeleton? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked as 'A', is the hyoid bone, which is not a part of the laryngeal skeleton.

 

The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located at the base of the tongue. While it is not considered a part of the larynx itself.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A - Hyoid bone

B - Thyroid cartilage

C - Epiglottis

D - Cricoid cartilage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid Cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is a large, shield-shaped cartilage in the larynx. It forms the prominent Adam's apple in the front of the neck and plays a role in sound production.

 

Option C. Epiglottis: The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilage  which belongs to larynx located at the base of the tongue. Its primary function is to prevent food and liquids from entering the airway (trachea) during swallowing.

 

Option D. Cricoid Cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located just below the thyroid cartilage. It is the only complete ring of cartilage in the larynx and provides structural support to the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A set of cartilages that are joined by ligaments and fibrous membranes make up the laryngeal skeleton:

 

  • Hyaline cartilage: The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages
  • Elastic cartilage: The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Great cardiac vein

 

The marked structure in the provided image is the great cardiac vein. The great cardiac vein runs along the anterior interventricular sulcus, accompanying the anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery or LAD). This vein collects blood from the anterior surfaces of both ventricles and drains into the coronary sinus.

 

The great cardiac vein is the largest of the veins draining the heart muscle (myocardium), and it is crucial in returning deoxygenated blood from the myocardium to the coronary sinus and eventually into the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cardiac vein: These veins drain directly into the right atrium and do not run in the anterior interventricular sulcus. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Middle cardiac vein: This vein runs in the posterior interventricular sulcus, accompanying the posterior interventricular artery. It is not located in the anterior interventricular sulcus, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Small cardiac vein: This vein is located on the right side of the heart and accompanies the right coronary artery. It is not associated with the anterior interventricular sulcus, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great cardiac vein runs along the anterior interventricular sulcus with the anterior interventricular artery and is crucial for draining blood from the anterior aspects of the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause a pleural pathology? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used primarily in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and increasing insulin sensitivity. Metformin is not associated with pleural pathologies, making it the correct choice in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methysergide: Methysergide is a medication used to prevent migraine headaches and is known for its potential to cause retroperitoneal and pleural fibrosis. This pleural pathology is a serious adverse effect, although the drug is not commonly used today due to this risk.

 

Option C. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of various cancers. One of its well-known side effects is pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as pulmonary fibrosis. Pleural involvement, including pleural effusions and fibrosis, can occur secondary to its pulmonary effects.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic used primarily for urinary tract infections. It can cause pulmonary reactions, including acute, subacute, and chronic pulmonary reactions. These reactions can involve the pleura, leading to pleural effusions and other pleural pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is not associated with causing pleural pathologies, unlike Methysergide, Bleomycin, and Nitrofurantoin, which have known risks of causing pleural and pulmonary complications.

questions.text: In 18th century British East India company used to transport which substance of abuse to China: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opium

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the British East India Company exported vast quantities of opium to China, leading to widespread addiction and the Opium Wars, which had significant geopolitical consequences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marijuana: A psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Option D. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, typically presenting with symptoms such as muscle weakness, paralysis, and respiratory failure rather than rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Associated with gastroenteritis that causes abdominal cramps and diarrhea, typically occurring 8-16 hours after consumption of contaminated food.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and other systemic symptoms, rather than immediate vomiting.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Sludder’s neuralgia is due to compression of anterior ethmoidal nerve by septal spur in the region of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle turbinate

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, also known as anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, occurs due to the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve. This nerve provides sensory innervation to parts of the nasal cavity and the anterior part of the cranial cavity. A septal spur, which is a sharp bony projection from the nasal septum, can impinge on the middle turbinate where the anterior ethmoidal nerve traverses. This compression can cause pain and headache in the regions supplied by the nerve, commonly leading to facial pain and nasal discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior turbinate: While the superior turbinate is located higher in the nasal cavity, it is not typically involved in the compression causing Sludder’s neuralgia. The anterior ethmoidal nerve runs closer to the middle turbinate.

 

Option B. Inferior turbinate: The inferior turbinate is situated lower in the nasal cavity and does not typically come into contact with the septal spur affecting the anterior ethmoidal nerve. Therefore, it is not involved in Sludder’s neuralgia.

 

Option D. Supreme turbinate: The supreme turbinate is an anatomical variant that some individuals have above the superior turbinate. This is not commonly implicated in conditions involving the anterior ethmoidal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, or anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, is caused by the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve by a septal spur in the region of the middle turbinate. This condition results in facial pain and headache due to nerve irritation.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to OCP use? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboembolism

 

Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to the use of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs). The use of combined oral contraceptives (COCs) can significantly increase the risk of venous thromboembolism, particularly in individuals with a history of thromboembolic events or known thrombogenic mutations.

 

Absolute Contraindications of Combined OCPs according to the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria:

 

  • MEC Category 4: Unacceptable health risk if the method is used.
    • Breastfeeding and < 6 weeks postpartum
    • Not breastfeeding; < 21 days postpartum with risk factors for Venous Thromboembolism
    • Age ≥ 35 years with smoking ≥ 15 cigarettes/day
    • Hypertension with systolic BP ≥ 160 OR Diastolic BP ≥ 100 mmHg
    • Hypertension with vascular disease
    • History of DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • Acute DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • DVT/Pulmonary embolism on anticoagulant therapy
    • Major surgery with prolonged immobilization
    • Known thrombogenic mutations (e.g., Factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, protein S, C, antithrombin deficiency)
    • Current and history of ischemic heart disease
    • Stroke (history of cerebrovascular disease)
    • Complicated valvular heart disease
    • Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome
    • Migraine with aura (any age)
    • Current breast cancer
    • Severe cirrhosis
    • Hepatocellular adenoma/carcinoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Renal Disease: Chronic renal disease is not an absolute contraindication but requires careful consideration depending on the severity and associated conditions.

 

Option C. History of Amenorrhea: A history of amenorrhea is not an absolute contraindication to the use of OCPs.

 

Option D. Diabetes Mellitus: Diabetes mellitus is not an absolute contraindication. However, it requires careful monitoring, especially if the patient has vascular complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to the use of combined oral contraceptives (COCs) due to the increased risk of venous thromboembolism associated with these medications.

questions.text: The patient visiting the outpatient department exhibits skin manifestations linked to a disease that includes Raynaud’s phenomenon. What is this skin manifestation shown below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salt and pepper pigmentation.

 

  • The presented clinical scenario indicates systemic sclerosis, a complex autoimmune condition of uncertain origin with diverse clinical manifestations.
  • It leads to considerable disability and mortality, affecting nearly all organs.
  • The defining feature of systemic sclerosis is scleroderma, characterized by thickened and indurated skin.

 

Systemic sclerosis

 

It also presents with typical skin manifestations of Raynaud phenomenon, which include the characteristic white discoloration of the fingers due to vasospasm and bluish discoloration of the fingertips as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The skin has a salt-and-pepper appearance when there is a loss of pigmentation, which is most noticeable on the upper back (as given in the question), chest, and scalp.
  • Sclerodactyly and sclerosis extending proximal to the metacarpophalangeal joints with or without contractures.

 

 

  • Loss of fingertip pulp
  • Vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences
  • Puffy fingers in early disease
  • Severe flexion contractures
  • Expressionless facies, mat-like telangiectasias, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and a beak-like nose can be seen as shown in the image below

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Poikiloderma is a skin disorder characterized by (ATP)

 

  • Atrophy
  • Telangiectasias
  • Pigment abnormalities Hypo and hyper

 

 

It is seen in ionizing radiation-damaged skin and Dermatomyositis.

 

Option C: Sometimes the color of the hair can change to white in the amelanotic lesions of vitiligo. It is known as leukotrichia.

 

Option D: Sharply demarcated depigmented macules are a hallmark of vitiligo. It results from the loss of melanocytes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Salt and Pepper pigmentation' is a cutaneous manifestation often seen in systemic sclerosis, a condition which also commonly presents with Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 56 page no 56.4

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 2779

questions.text: Whole- body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT limbs

 

Explanation:

 

CT Limbs is not included in the whole-body CT of a trauma patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Head: Non-contrast CT (NCCT) of the head to check for any intracranial hemorrhages or fractures.

 

Option B. CT Cervical Spine: NCCT of the cervical spine to assess for any fractures or dislocations that may compromise the spinal cord.

 

Option D. CT Abdomen: Contrast-enhanced CT of the torso, including the abdomen and pelvis, to evaluate for internal injuries such as organ lacerations, bleeding, or other trauma-related abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole-body CT or trauma CT includes:

 

  1. NCCT head
  2. NCCT C-spine
  3. Contrast-enhanced CT of torso

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.text: A young female is brought to the emergency department. Attendants inform that she has consumed 100 tablets of aspirin. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

 

Aspirin poisoning (Salicylism)

 

Respiratory Center Stimulation

↓

Hyperventilation

↓

↓CO2

↓

Respiratory Alkalosis → Reversible

↓

Metabolic Acidosis → Irreversible

 

Treatment - DOC is sodium bicarbonate (NaHC03)

  •  Reverses metabolic acidosis
  •  Helps in aspirin excretion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores: N-acetyl cysteine is an antidote for paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option B. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is useful in organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option C. Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia: Glucagon is antidote in beta-blocker toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium Bicarbonate is the treatment of choice in aspirin poisoning, as it helps to alkalize the urine and enhance the excretion of salicylates, while also correcting metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters W, X, Y, and Z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. W Y

 

Explanation:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene. In the case of this question, product A is formed by including specific

segments and excluding others through the process of alternative splicing.

 

  • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5.
    • Promoter W Required for segment 1.
    • Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5.
    • Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.

 

Thus, the combination of Promoters W and Y will result in the production of sequence A by including

the correct segments and excluding segment 2.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a (W, X, Y): This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it

    is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.

  • Option b (W, Z): Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A.
  • Option c (WX): Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene.

 

Using promoters W, Y will yield product A by including segments 1, 3, 4, and 5 and removing segment 2 through alternative splicing.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: No agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while positive agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the initial two dilutions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody excess

 

  • Marrack proposed the lattice hypothesis → Multivalent antigens combine with Bivalent antibodies
  • Lattice is formed only when antigen and antibodies are in proportion.
  • If antigen or antibodies ,any of them is in excess - there is no lattice formation
  • The absence of a positive test result in the initial two tubes can be attributed to the prozone phenomenon.
  • In this scenario, there is an excess of antibodies in comparison to antigens, which results in a lack of robust or noticeable precipitation.

 

Zone phenomenon:

 

  1. Prozone = Ab excess = Absent
  2. Zone of equivalence = Proper proportion = Peak
  3. Post zone = Ag excess = Absent

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Incorrect antigen: If the antigen were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option B. Incorrect antibody: If the antibody were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option D. Antigen excess: Antigen excess would cause a postzone phenomenon, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prozone phenomenon, where antibody excess prevents agglutination, can account for the lack of agglutination in low dilution samples.
